title-group.article-title: Out‐of‐Court Restructurings and the Resolution of Financial Distress: Section 3(a)(9) Compared to Investment‐Bank‐Managed Exchange Offers*

abstract.p: To avoid bankruptcy, financially distressed firms often undertake out‐of‐court restructurings, which take the form of exchange offers for firms with public debt outstanding. We examine the choice between potentially lower cost, faster offers of unregistered securities under Section 3(a)(9) of the Securities Act and investment‐bank‐managed exchange offers. We find that investment bank participation relates negatively to commercial bank debt outstanding but positively to bank loan concessions, firm size, number of debt contracts outstanding, and proposed debt reduction. Investment‐bank‐managed exchange offers result in greater debt reduction and better postrestructuring operating performance.

sec.label: I.
sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: In this article, we examine the relation between investment bank participation in public‐debt exchange offers by financially distressed firms and the composition and the outcome of the offer. Financial theory suggests that investment banks create value by mitigating impediments to economic transactions. Although many empirical studies support this premise, several recent studies question the value added by investment banks. Public‐debt exchange offers by firms in financial distress provide an interesting sample for studying the role of investment banks in a market economy.

Firms in financial distress face severe impediments to the success of their public‐debt restructurings. They must choose between offers of unregistered securities under Section 3(a)(9) of the Securities Act of 1933 (Section 3(a)(9) exchange offers), in which they cannot use the services of an intermediary, and investment‐bank‐managed exchange offers (IBMEOs). Our study provides knowledge on how investment banks help firms resolve financial distress and presents new insights into the benefits of using investment banks to facilitate financial transactions. It also provides additional tests of many extant theories of financial intermediation.

We investigate three questions central to the role and effectiveness of investment banks in mitigating impediments to public‐debt exchange offers by distressed firms. First, we ask if distressed firms that choose to undertake IBMEOs are ex ante different from distressed firms that choose Section 3(a)(9) exchange offers. Second, we ask if firms that undertake IBMEOs use the composition of the exchange offer or some other means to mitigate impediments to a public‐debt restructuring. Third, we ask how successful, both for the immediate objective of avoiding Chapter 11 bankruptcy and the overriding objective of the resolution of financial distress, are IBMEOs when compared to Section 3(a)(9) exchange offers.

Our study examines a sample of 89 exchange offers by financially distressed firms from 1980 to 1994. We find that the probability that a firm chooses an IBMEO is positively related to firm size, the number of debt contracts outstanding, proposed debt reduction, and bank loan concessions. The use of investment banks decreases as the percentage of bank debt increases and if at least one other firm in the industry recently has conducted a Section 3(a)(9) exchange offer. These findings suggest that firms choose investment banks because they reduce transaction costs arising from complex negotiations and when restructuring public debt is pivotal to avoiding Chapter 11 bankruptcy.

To determine whether firms rely on offer design or the investment bank to mitigate impediments to exchange offers, we examine the composition of exchange offers. We document that investment‐bank‐managed exchange offers are less likely to include senior claims. When IBMEOs do include senior claims, the offer contains a lower percentage of senior claims than Section 3(a)(9) exchange offers. These results suggest that firms that undertake IBMEOs do not rely on offer design to mitigate impediments to exchange offers and investment banks certify the value of the securities offered.

We also examine several measures of restructuring success: the frequency with which the exchanges are completed, tendering rates (as a percentage of the minimum amount of securities sought), acceptance rates, avoidance of Chapter 11 bankruptcy, the actual debt reduction, and postrestructuring performance. We find no difference between the two subsamples for reported tendering rates or the frequency with which firms avoid Chapter 11 bankruptcy. We observe a higher completion rate for firms that undertake Section 3(a)(9) exchange offers, likely because they pursue less difficult objectives. If the exchange offer is not completed, tendered bonds are not accepted. Because the completion rate is lower for IBMEOs, the acceptance rate is also lower. Yet, we find that IBMEOs result in greater actual debt reduction. Firms that undertake IBMEOs and firms that conduct Section 3(a)(9) exchange offers exhibit similar operating performance for the year prior to restructuring. However, by the second year after the restructuring, firms that undertake IBMEOs achieve significantly better operating performance than firms that conduct Section 3(a)(9) exchange offers.

The article is organized as follows. Section II reviews the prior literature that serves as a background for our study. Section III presents a discussion of regulations related to investment bank involvement in exchange offers. Section IV describes the sample and method and Section V presents our results. Section VI concludes.

sec.label: II.
sec.title: Background and Previous Research
sec.p: Exchange offers by firms in financial distress have lower transaction costs and are completed in a shorter time than reorganization under Chapter 11 (Franks and Torous1994). Furthermore, Section 3(a)(9) of the Securities Act of 1933 is advantageous because it allows the distressed firm to avoid the lengthy job of registering the new securities offered in exchange for outstanding public debt.1However, the Securities Act prohibits paying a third party to promote such an exchange. Rather than take advantage of Section 3(a)(9) and avoid the registration process, many distressed firms choose to employ investment banks to manage and promote their exchange offers. These firms pay fees to investment banks, incur costs associated with the registration of new securities, and continue to bear the costs of distress during the registration process. That many firms choose to incur the additional costs associated with an IBMEO raises interesting questions regarding the economic benefits of involving investment banks in an out‐of‐court restructuring and, more generally, the benefits of using investment banks to facilitate transactions in financial markets.

Although the immediate objective of exchange offers is to reduce the cash required to meet debt service in order to avoid Chapter 11 bankruptcy, the more general objective is the resolution of financial distress. However, recent research questions the effectiveness of out‐of‐court restructurings in resolving financial distress. For example, Gilson (1997) finds that leverage remains high following out‐of‐court debt restructurings and that a high percentage of these firms subsequently file for bankruptcy or undergo a second out‐of‐court restructuring. Furthermore, many studies demonstrate the severity of impediments to out‐of‐court public debt restructurings. Foremost among these impediments are asymmetric information, transaction costs, and holdout problems.2

Theorists propose that financial intermediaries create value by reducing the impediments to economic transactions (Benston and Smith1976; Diamond1984; Chemmanur and Fulghieri1994). Much of the existing empirical evidence on investment banks supports this premise. For instance, Booth and Smith (1986), Carter and Manaster (1990), and Michaely and Shaw (1994) present evidence suggesting that investment banks certify the value of security offerings. Servaes and Zenner (1996) find that investment banks minimize transactions costs in corporate acquisitions. However, new studies raise new questions on the role of investment banks in financial transactions. Beatty and Welch (1996) find opposite empirical relations from those reported by Carter and Manaster (1990) and Michaely and Shaw (1994). Rau (2000) argues that investment banks advising acquiring firms in mergers and acquisitions build their reputation merely by completing deals, not by creating value for their clients. Thus, the role of investment banks in financial transactions remains an important empirical issue.

Studies of financially distressed firms suggest that the success of an out‐of‐court restructuring of public and private debt to avoid bankruptcy critically depends on a firm's ability to restructure its public debt (Asquith, Gertner, and Scharfstein1994; James1995). Yet, coordination and asymmetric information problems are severe for financially distressed firms attempting an out‐of‐court debt restructuring. Intermediation theory suggests that investment banks could play a positive role in this process by helping to facilitate a successful public‐debt exchange offer that leads to the resolution of financial distress.

sec.label: III.
sec.title: Regulation Related to Investment Banks and Public‐Debt Exchange Offers
sec.p: In a public‐debt exchange offer, the firm issues new securities and offers existing public bondholders the opportunity to exchange the new securities for securities outstanding. Financially distressed firms conducting a public‐debt exchange offer in compliance with Section 3(a)(9) of the Securities Act may forgo registration of the new securities.

Financially distressed companies have either defaulted on their debt, or they anticipate a default, and may have to file for bankruptcy if the exchange offer is not successfully completed in a timely fashion. To save time and money and avoid registration delays that could cause the firm to file for bankruptcy, these firms often choose to conduct a Section 3(a)(9) exchange offer without a registration statement. In 1986, firms sought $5.5 billion in securities in unregistered exchange offers (San Francisco Chronicle[May 26, 1987]).

However, Section 3(a)(9) prevents investment banks from promoting or marketing unregistered securities offered in an exchange. Firms that conduct exchange offers exempt from registration under Section 3(a)(9) cannot have a dealer manager for the exchange and cannot pay a commission to brokers, dealers, or salespersons for soliciting tenders pursuant to the exchange. The firm cannot pay an investment bank to solicit tenders, and any investment bank receiving compensation from the firm may not make a recommendation to bondholders regarding the tender of securities pursuant to the exchange. Offers are made pursuant to an offering circular. Firms often hire an information agent. In aForbesarticle (December 1, 1986), Paul Levy, a Drexel Burnham Lambert top executive, states that Drexel Burnham Lambert has specifically prohibited its retail system from involvement in these transactions to comply with the Securities Act. The investment bank's fees are also lower. Drexel's fee for advising a firm on the structure of an exchange under Section 3(a)(9) is about 1.25% of the market value of securities sought.

The advantage to the firm of offering registered securities in an exchange is that investment banks may market and promote the securities offered and solicit tenders. Investment banks act as dealer managers for exchange offers with registration statements and often agree to make a market in the new securities upon completion of the exchange. Investment banks typically earn monthly advisory fees that range from $75,000 to $250,000 plus a success fee of up to $1 million. Transaction fees are 1–2% of the value of securities sought (Euromoney[June 1, 1990]). Proxy statements indicate that fees generally include a fixed retainer as well. Since the fixed component is spread out over a larger base, total fees on a percentage basis vary with the size of the exchange offer. Firms often report investment bank fees for the management of the exchange offer bundled with fees for other restructuring services, such as arranging for additional financing and underwriting new securities. The investment bank generally receives additional fees for these services if it is not managing the exchange. The total fees paid to investment banks for restructuring services can be as high as five to seven percent of the face value of debt sought.

As noted, the Securities Act permits investment banks to advise firms on the design of a Section 3(a)(9) exchange offer but prohibits them from acting as an intermediary between the firm and its bondholders. In this article, we define investment‐bank participation in an exchange offer as involving the retail system of the investment bank. Under our definition, the investment bank serves as an intermediary between the firm and bondholders. Thus, we distinguish between transactions with an investment bank serving as an intermediary and transactions in which there is either no investment bank or the investment bank only offers advice on the structure of the exchange.

sec.label: A.
sec.title: Sample Selection
sec.p: We obtain a sample of out‐of‐court restructurings between 1980 and 1994 fromDow Jones Interactiveusing the key wordsdebt swap,financial restructuring,exchange offer, anddebt restructuring. For firms identified in the key word search, we read theWall Street JournalorDow Jones News Servicearticles to determine if the company has undertaken an exchange offer and if it is in financial distress. Following Brown, James, and Mooradian (1993), we consider a company to be financially distressed if theWall Street JournalorDow Jonesarticle indicates that the goal of the exchange is to avoid bankruptcy or to remedy either a preexisting or expected default. We exclude firms operating under bankruptcy protection, regulated utilities, and financial institutions. Our final sample comprises 89 public debt exchange offers by financially distressed firms.

We determine the terms of the offer from theWall Street Journalor theMoody's Manual. Since exchange offers are often amended while the offer is outstanding, we follow James (1996) and classify offers by the terms of the final offer to bondholders. We obtain financial data from Compustat, 10‐K filings, annual shareholder reports, and theMoody'sannual reports. We classify exchange offers as completed if tendered securities are accepted. Typically, exchange offers are conditioned on the firm tendering a minimum percentage of bonds outstanding. Exchange offers are withdrawn and tendered securities returned to bondholders if a sufficient number of bonds are not tendered.

We obtain information on investment‐bank participation from news articles describing the offer, the firm's annual report, and Salomon Brothers U.S. Corporate Bond Research High Yield Restructuring Report. Information on bank debt restructurings comes from the firms' annual reports,Moody's Manuals, and news articles in theDow Jones Interactivedatabase around the time of the exchange offer. We classify a bank loan restructuring as a bank concession if the bank agrees to reduce the principal amount of its loan in exchange for stock or warrants following completion of the public‐debt exchange.

sec.label: B.
sec.title: Methodology
sec.p: Our first step in analyzing the role of investment banks in distressed exchange offers is to estimate the likelihood that a firm chooses an investment bank managed exchange offer rather than a Section 3(a)(9) exchange. We base our estimates on ex ante firm characteristics and exchange offer objectives. However, factors that influence why firms use investment banks, such as firm size or the proportion of bank debt, may also affect the design and outcome of the offer. These endogenous relations can create a sample bias and make it difficult to interpret our analyses of exchange‐offer composition or exchange‐offer contribution toward the resolution of financial distress.

To control for this potential bias when we analyze offer design and actual debt reduction, we use two‐stage selection models for treatment effects (investment bank participation in this case) in addition to ordinary least squares (OLS).3We estimate a probit model for investment bank choice and use the inverse Mills ratio and a consistent estimate of standard errors to control for selection bias in our second‐stage regressions. We also replicate our analysis on a subsample of 58 firms matched on size and financial characteristics. Our results on the matched sample are qualitatively and statistically similar to those reported for the full sample.

fn.p: See Heckman (1979), Greene (1981), and Barnow, Cain, and Goldberger (1981) for the development of these two‐stage selection models. Maddala (1983) and Greene (2000) provide descriptions of the methods of estimation.

sec.title: Descriptive Statistics of Exchange Offer Characteristics by Investment Bank Involvement

For these transactions, we examine theMoody's Manualcorresponding to the fiscal year ending just prior to the exchange offer to determine whether the investment bank involved in the transaction had previously underwritten the firm's bonds. Firms amend 54% of the exchange offers. IBMEOs are amended as frequently as Section 3(a)(9) offers (54% for both) but are extended less often (69% compared to 100%). In 81% of all offers, firms extend their completion dates beyond the original proposed completion date, which suggests that firms bargain with bondholders over the terms of the offer. The mean (median) number of extensions when an investment bank is involved is two (two) compared to five (three) when an investment bank is not involved. Extensions (each of which requires advertising, circulars, etc.) indicate that the firm failed to gain bondholder approval within the initially expected time frame, resulting in the need for additional and potentially more costly efforts to get bondholders to tender. Therefore, the lower frequency and smaller number of extensions associated with investment‐bank participation support the premise that investment banks reduce transaction costs by more effectively bargaining with bondholders.

To gain information on the additional time and cost associated with choosing an IBMEO, we examine the time required to complete the offer. We calculate this time as the number of days between the first announcement date and the final expiration of the exchange offer.4The mean (median) time from the announcement to the completion of exchange offers is 160 (125) days for the entire sample, with a maximum (minimum) of 720 (28) days. The mean (median) for IBMEOs is 177 (154) days, with a maximum (minimum) of 454 (28) days. For Section 3(a)(9) exchange offers the mean (median) time to completion is 135 (90) days, with a maximum (minimum) of 720 (28) days. As we expect, since a registration statement is not required, the median time to completion is significantly shorter for Section 3(a)(9) exchanges.

fn.p: The total time required to restructure debt claims is longer than the time required to complete the exchange offer, particularly for firms that do not receive adequate tendering rates to avoid Chapter 11 bankruptcy or that engage in lengthy negotiations with private creditors. Estimates of the total time required to restructure debt outside of Chapter 11 bankruptcy range from 9 to 17 months (Gilson et al.1990; Asquith et al.1994; Franks and Torous1994).

Panel A oftable 2presents the financial characteristics of the firms that choose IBMEOs and those that choose Section 3(a)(9) offers. Panel B gives exchange‐offer characteristics. We follow Franks and Torous (1994) and use firm size and the number of long‐term debt contracts listed in theMoody's Manualas our proxy for bargaining complexity. Large firms and firms with a greater number of long‐term debt contracts are likely to have more parties involved in the negotiations, making it more difficult for them to organize creditors and increasing the complexity of the transaction. Bondholders often establish informal creditor committees to bargain with management over a restructuring plan. In 31% of the cases in which the firm employs an investment bank, we can identify the investment bank(s) that public bondholders hire as their financial advisors for the restructuring. In 24% of these cases, bondholders have more than one advisor, one advisor to represent junior bondholders and another for the senior bondholders.

Supporting the premise that investment banks can reduce these transaction costs, firms that employ investment banks are significantly larger ($454.14 million in assets compared to $95.18 million) and have significantly more long‐term debt contracts (seven compared to five) than firms without investment banks (p‐values equal 0.00 and 0.04, respectively). Consistent with the idea that firms choose IBMEOs when completion of the public debt restructuring is more critical to avoiding Chapter 11, firms that choose an investment bank have lower ratios of bank debt to total debt (0.03 compared to 0.23,p‐value equals 0.02). Ratios of public debt to total debt are not statistically different across the two subsamples.

However, firms that choose investment banks are also more likely to have obtained a bank loan concession (13% compared to 3%,p‐value equals 0.07). As the percentage of bank debt increases, the bank debt is more likely to be impaired and the relative importance of the commercial bank to any out‐of‐court restructuring increases. This increased importance indicates a greater role for commercial banks. But, when banks make a concession, they condition the concession on the successful completion of the public debt exchange offer, which makes completion of the public‐debt exchange more critical to avoiding Chapter 11. Thus, the data suggest that firms choose IBMEOs when the restructuring of public debt is more critical to the resolution of financial distress.

The firms in both subsamples are very highly leveraged. The ratios that indicate financial condition are not significantly different across the two subsamples. The median leverage ratios (based on book values) are 0.73 and 0.72, respectively, for the firms undertaking investment‐bank‐managed and Section 3(a)(9) exchange offers. Solvency ratios (the total debt divided by the total debt plus the book value of common stock) are high and coverage ratios (the operating cash flow divided by the interest expense) are less than 1. The data indicate that firms in both subsamples have large debt burdens and are cash‐flow constrained.

Since firms in both subsamples are cash‐flow constrained, firms in both subsamples seek to reduce cash‐flow obligations. Although firms in both subsamples have large debt burdens, they could differ on their potential costs from continuing to operate with high leverage and thus differ on the need to reduce leverage. Therefore, some firms might seek to reduce cash flow obligations without reducing public debt outstanding, since holdout and asymmetric information problems, which are impediments to the exchange, are more severe for leverage‐reducing exchange offers. In general, exchange offers with no debt reduction involve the issuance of a new debt security with interest payable in common stock or cash at the firm's option. The pay‐in‐kind feature implies a reduction in the firm's cash flow obligations.

Firms for which the potential costs of continued high leverage are greater are more likely to seek greater debt reduction, which is a more difficult objective. Furthermore, if investment banks are able to mitigate the more severe impediments to leverage‐reducing exchange offers, we would expect firms that seek greater debt reduction to choose IBMEOs. Panel B oftable 2shows that, for a smaller percentage of IBMEOs relative to Section 3(a)(9) exchange offers, firms seek no public debt reduction (22% compared to 51%,p‐value equals 0.00). Furthermore, firms that use investment banks seek greater reduction in public debt outstanding (medians are 42% compared to zero,p‐value is 0.00). Thus, the data indicate that firms that need greater leverage reduction choose IBMEOs.

To further explore why firms use investment banks, we examine intangible assets and fixed assets as a fraction of the total assets of the firm. Titman and Wessels (1988) and Rajan and Zingales (1995) argue that firms with more fixed assets, which can be liquidated, are easier to monitor and bear lower agency costs of debt. Firms with more intangible assets are more susceptible to risk shifting and bear higher agency costs of debt. These authors find that the fraction of debt in the capital structure is negatively related to intangible assets. Confirming our conjecture that firms choose an investment bank because the costs of continued high leverage are greater, we find that the mean (median) ratio of intangible assets to total assets is 0.12 (0.03) for firms that use investment banks compared to 0.04 (0.00) for firms that choose a Section 3(a)(9) offer. These results are significantly different at the 1% (5%) level. Similarly, the mean (median) ratio of fixed assets to total assets is 0.41 (0.39) for firms that use an investment bank compared to 0.53 (0.61) for Section 3(a)(9) firms, both significantly different at the 5% level.

We also examine whether growth opportunities are related to a firm's choice of an IBMEO over a Section 3(a)(9) offer. We analyze the 2‐year growth rate in the firms' operating cash flow/sales, the firms' 2‐year employee growth rate, and the firms' market‐to‐book asset ratios. With and without industry adjustments, we find no differences between firms that use investment banks and those that do not.

sec.label: C.
sec.title: Why Do Distressed Firms Use Investment Banks to Manage Their Exchange Offers?
sec.p: To gain additional insight on why distressed firms employ investment banks to facilitate their exchange offers, we use a probit model to estimate the likelihood of investment bank involvement in the restructurings. The probit serves as the first stage in two‐stage selections models that control for selection bias. We use the inverse Mills ratio from the probit estimation to control for selection bias in our second‐stage analyses of the composition of the offer, the debt reduction achieved in the exchange, and postrestructuring performance. We use firm size (the natural logarithm of assets) and the number of long‐term debt contracts as proxies for transaction costs associated with more complex restructurings. The percentage of bank debt and a dummy variable for bank concessions control for the relative importance, in avoiding Chapter 11, of restructuring commercial bank debt compared public debt. We use the coverage ratio and the solvency ratio to control for financial condition. We include the proposed percentage of debt reduction, which serves as a proxy for the difficulty of attaining the objective of the exchange offer and as a proxy for the severity of the potential costs of continuing to operate with a suboptimal capital structure.5If at least one other firm in the industry has recently conducted a Section 3(a)(9) exchange offer, a manager might reasonably think that an offer by his firm without using an investment bank would be well received. To control for such industry clustering, we include a dummy variable that is 1 if at least one other firm in the sample firm's two‐digit SIC code has conducted a Section 3(a)(9) exchange offer within the previous 3 years, and zero if not. We also use the three‐digit SIC code and a 2‐year window with similar qualitative results.

Table 3presents the results of out probit estimation. Model 1 uses firm size as a proxy for transaction costs. Model 2 uses the number of debt contracts.6Our results suggest that investment banks manage more complex exchange offers with more difficult objectives. Consistent with the premise that investment banks reduce transaction costs associated with complex bargaining, the likelihood of investment‐bank involvement is positively related to firm size (the number of debt contracts), significant at the 1% (5%) level. Firms that seek greater debt reduction are more likely to use an investment bank (significant at the 5% level). Combined with the fact that such firms have a greater proportion of intangible assets, this finding suggests that the ability of an investment bank to facilitate the exchange is more important when the firm's expected costs of continuing with a suboptimal capital structure are higher. Consistent with industry clustering of Section 3(a)(9) exchange offers, we find that the likelihood of choosing an investment bank is less if at least one other firm in the industry has conducted a Section 3(a)(9) exchange within the last 3 years. Our results also indicate that investment and commercial banks play both substitute and complementary roles in restructuring the public debt of distressed firms. As bank debt increases, the exchange offer is less critical to avoiding Chapter 11, and the likelihood that an investment bank is involved is lower (significant at the 10% level in Model 2). However, when a bank makes a concession, the likelihood of investment bank involvement increases (significant at the 10% level). Since a bank concession is generally contingent on completion of the public debt exchange, the exchange offer is pivotal to avoiding Chapter 11. Thus, the higher likelihood of investment‐bank involvement supports the premise that firms choose an investment bank to facilitate the exchange offer when the restructuring is critical to avoiding Chapter 11.

We also examine the identity of the investment banks chosen and use two methods to evaluate their reputation for expertise in the resolution of financial distress. First, following Megginson and Weiss (1991), we calculate the market share of the investment banks based on the value of the debt securities sought in the exchange. When two or more investment banks are involved, we assign each investment bank full credit for the transaction. Thus, it appears that boutique specialists can effectively compete with large investment banks and together these two groups dominate the market for facilitating exchange offers by distressed firms.

To further test this premise we repeat all our tests on the composition of the exchange offer and on the success of the exchange offer using a bulge bracket dummy variable, the market share proxy and a high‐leverage specialist dummy variable. We find no systematic differences based on these three reputation measures.

In results not reported here, we find that proposed debt reduction is a determinant of investment bank participation but that the investment bank does not influence the proposed reduction.

sec.label: D.
sec.title: The Composition of Exchange Offers and Investment Bank Involvement
sec.p: Gertner and Scharfstein (1991) and Brown et al. (1993) demonstrate that, by offering to exchange senior claims for outstanding public debt, firms can mitigate their severe holdout and asymmetric information problems. Thus, all firms that undertake an exchange offer have the incentive to use this method to increase the likelihood of a successful exchange. The important questions are (1) why do not all distressed firms undertaking an exchange offer do this, and (2) if they all do not do so, are there alternatives that also increase the likelihood of a successful exchange?

The answer to the first question is that offering senior claims limits a firm's ability to reduce debt and can result in the firm incurring the costs of continuing to operate with a suboptimal capital structure. The firm is constrained in its ability to tailor the exchange offer to reduce debt and make a greater contribution toward resolving financial distress.

Financial theory and existing evidence on security offerings suggest a potential answer to the second question. Investment banks mitigate information problems by certifying the value of securities offered in an exchange. If investment banks certify the value of the securities offered in distressed public debt restructurings, we expect firms that undertake IBMEOs to offer securities that are more difficult to evaluate, such as equity or junior debt claims. Following James (1996), we use the dollar ratio of senior‐debt offered to junior‐debt sought in the exchange offer as a proxy for the degree of information problems. If investment banks can mitigate information problems, we expect IBMEOs to comprise less senior debt and have a lower ratio of senior‐debt offered to junior‐debt sought.

In our regressions for the full sample of exchange offers, we find that senior‐debt offered per dollar of junior‐debt sought is negatively related to investment‐bank involvement (significant at the 1% level) in both the OLS and the selection models. This finding suggests that firms rely more on the investment banks' ability to certify the value of securities offered rather than the composition of the offer to mitigate impediments to distressed exchange offers.

To examine an alternative hypothesis, that investment banks merely design offers to mitigate holdout problems, we include the number of outstanding public bond issues (a proxy for holdouts) and test for an interaction between investment bank involvement and the number of bond issues. We find no support for the alternative hypothesis.

Consistent with the idea that larger firms undergo more complex restructurings that need to use senior securities to induce tendering, we find that in the selection model firm size is positive and significant. Finally, the bank debt of firms with a greater proportion of bank debt is more likely to be impaired. Given the seniority of bank debt, if bank debt is impaired, these firms are unable to offer claims that are effectively senior to outstanding public debt. Confirming James (1996), we find that firms with a greater proportion of bank debt offer a lower proportion of senior debt.

Since preexisting senior private (nonbank) debt could limit the ability of a firm to offer new senior debt in the exchange offer, we examine the percentage of the preexisting private debt senior to the securities sought in the exchange. The average percentage of total debt that is senior private debt for firms that undertake IBMEOs is 6.75%. This percentage is not significantly different than that for firms undertaking Section 3(a)(9) offers (5.88%). When we also include the percentage of private senior debt as a control variable in the regressions, we find no relation. The relations with all other variables remain qualitatively and statistically similar to those reported in the table.

As an additional test of the investment bank certification hypothesis, we reestimate our regressions on the subsample of 47 debt‐for‐debt exchange offers. Firms that propose greater debt reduction generally offer greater amounts of equity rather than debt. Following from the earlier analysis, such firms are also more likely to choose an IBMEO. Thus, for exchange offers in which at least some equity is offered to public bondholders, the amount of senior‐debt offered is negatively related to investment bank involvement.

We might conclude incorrectly that the negative relation between the amount of senior‐debt offered and investment‐bank involvement is strictly driven by the positive relation between the need for debt reduction and investment bank involvement. To demonstrate a broader negative relation between these two factors, we restrict our analysis to exchange offers in which only new debt is offered to public bondholders. The amount of senior‐debt offered per dollar of junior‐debt sought is negatively related to investment bank involvement in both the OLS and the selection model for the 47 all‐debt transactions (significant at the 1% and 5% levels, respectively). Relatedness to control variables is similar to those reported for the full sample of equity and all‐debt offers. These results confirm our previous tests. They also provide additional evidence supporting the premise that investment banks certify the value of securities offered in public debt exchange offers.

Firms often do not accept tendered securities if they do not reach the minimum number of securities sought. We calculate an acceptance rate, which is the percentage of securities outstanding that are tendered for completed exchange offers, and zero for exchange offers that are withdrawn or expire with no bonds accepted. As expected given the higher completion rate, the acceptance rate is greater for Section 3(a)(9) exchange offers (19% compared to 57%,p‐value equals 0.05). The percentages of firms that survive 2 years (50% compared to 60%) and 5 years (39% compared to 40%) without filing for bankruptcy are also not statistically different. We observe a similar pattern when we examine firms' ability to avoid any additional restructuring activities (43% compared to 49% over 2 years and 30% compared to 26% over 5 years). These data support Gilson's (1997) finding that out‐of‐court restructurings are frequently not successful and are followed by additional restructuring activities. As expected, given the less difficult objective of Section 3(a)(9) exchange offers, firms that undertake these exchanges are more likely to complete them. However, firms that use Section 3(a)(9) exchange offers are not more likely to avoid Chapter 11 bankruptcy or other restructuring activities.

To analyze the success of the exchange offer in reducing debt, we calculate the actual debt reduction as the product of the proposed debt reduction and the acceptance rate. If the exchange offer is not completed, no tenders are accepted, and the actual debt reduction is zero. To ensure that the relation between actual reduction and the choice of investment bank is not spuriously related to the higher proposed debt reduction in IBMEOs, we examine the correlations between actual debt reduction, proposed debt reduction, and the acceptance rate. In results not reported in the table, we find that, for all transactions (investment bank, Section 3(a)(9)), the correlation between actual debt reduction and proposed reduction is 0.62 (0.53, 0.78), and the correlation with the acceptance rate 0.48 (0.62, 0.33). Proposed debt reduction and the acceptance rate both influence the actual debt reduction. In determining actual reduction for IBMEOs, the acceptance rate is more important, that is, more highly correlated, than is the proposed debt reduction.

For the more general objective of reducing debt and resolving financial distress, IBMEOs appear to be more successful than Section 3(a)(9) exchange offers. For completed offers, the median debt reduction is 38% for IBMEOs compared to zero for Section 3(a)(9) transactions (p‐value equals 0.01). Moreover, 62% of the Section 3(a)(9) transactions do not achieve any debt reduction, compared to 22% of the investment‐bank‐managed transactions (p‐value equals 0.00).

To examine the relation between the amount of debt reduction achieved and investment‐bank involvement, we regress the actual proportional debt reduction against the same set of independent variables used to analyze offer composition. Since both investment‐bank involvement and a commercial‐bank concession could mitigate problems that impede exchange offers, we expect to find positive relations between public debt reduction and both the dummy variable for a commercial bank concession and the dummy variable for investment bank involvement. Since complexity of negotiations, and hence transaction costs, increase with size, we expect to find a negative relation between debt reduction and firm size. As the percentage of commercial‐bank debt increases, the resolution of financial distress depends more on a firm's ability to reduce the amount of bank debt outstanding rather than to reduce public debt. Therefore, we expect a negative relation between public‐debt reduction and the ratio of bank debt to total debt. We use the firm's solvency ratio (a proxy for debt overhang) and coverage ratio to control for the financial condition of the firm.

To ensure that we do not detect spurious correlation, we estimate all our regressions (without the bank concession dummy variable) on the subset of exchange offers that do not have bank concessions. Our results are qualitatively and statistically similar to those reported in the table.

For the regressions using all 89 (completed and withdrawn) exchange offers, we find a positive relation between actual debt reduction and investment‐bank involvement in both the Tobit model and the selection model (significant at the 5% and 1% levels, respectively). Actual debt reduction shows a positive relation with the commercial‐bank concession dummy variable (significant at the 5% level only in the Tobit model). Also, as we hypothesized, debt reduction is negatively related to firm size (significant at the 1% level).

The analysis on the subset of 53 completed exchange offers confirms the positive relation between debt reduction and investment‐bank management of the exchange. The relation between actual debt reduction and investment‐bank involvement for both the OLS and selection models is positive and significant at the 5% and 1% levels, respectively. The relatedness of the control variables is similar to those reported for the full sample of 89 exchange offers. Actual debt reduction is positively related to a bank concession (significant at the 1% level in the OLS model) and negatively related to firm size in both models. Debt reduction also decreases with the percentage of bank debt in the OLS model (significant at the 10% level). The results intable 8support the hypothesis that investment‐bank participation mitigates impediments to the resolution of financial distress in out‐of‐court restructurings. IBMEOs achieve greater actual debt reduction than Section 3(a)(9) exchanges.

As an additional test (not reported in the table) of the out‐of‐court restructurings' contribution toward the resolution of financial distress by reducing debt, we examine leverage ratios relative to industry medians (three‐digit SIC code median) before and after the restructuring. Gilson (1997) reports that, for 86.7% of firms undertaking out‐of‐court restructurings in his sample, leverage ratios remain above their respective industry medians. Consistent with Gilson (1997), we find that, following the exchange offer, 86.6% of the firms in our sample have leverage ratios above the industry median. However, for Section 3(a)(9) exchange offers, 100% remain above the industry median compared to 77.4% for investment‐bank‐managed offers (p‐value equals 0.01). Moreover, although the industry‐adjusted leverage ratios (firm leverage less industry median) before the exchange are not significantly different (0.48 for IBMEOs compared to 0.52 for Section 3(a)(9) exchange offers,p‐value equals 0.45), the firms that conduct IBMEOs have significantly lower industry‐adjusted leverage ratios after the exchange offer is completed (0.17 compared to 0.58,p‐value equals 0.00).

We also compare the unadjusted leverage and coverage ratios. We find that the median percentage change in the leverage ratio is −7.2% for IBMEOs compared to 11.9% for Section 3(a)(9) exchanges (significant at the 5% level). Additionally, the median firm that uses an investment bank has a leverage (coverage) ratio 2 years after the exchange offer of 0.50 (1.11) compared to a leverage (coverage) ratio of 0.79 (0.27) for firms taking advantage of Section 3(a)(9) (significant at the 10% and 5% levels, respectively). These findings support our evidence from the debt‐reduction analysis and suggest that IBMEOs are more successful than exchanges conducted under Section 3(a)(9) in reducing leverage and cash flow obligations. Thus, IBMEOs contribute more toward the resolution of financial distress.

sec.label: F.
sec.title: The Effect on Postrestructuring Operating Performance
sec.p: Financial distress arises from either too much debt or economic distress (see Andrade and Kaplan1998). Of the two, the latter is more serious and often attributed to a failing business model or a declining industry. However, if financial distress arising from too much debt is left uncorrected, distorted business decisions can lead to economic distress and the firm's decline in value as a going concern. Thus, good operating performance is one of the most important characteristics of a successful restructuring. Following previous researchers (e.g., Hotchkiss1995; Andrade and Kaplan1998), we analyze a firm's ability to exist as a going concern by examining its operating cash flow performance, which we define as earnings before interest, depreciation, and amortization (EBITDA). If investment banks are more successful in restructuring distressed firms, we expect that firms that use investment banks to manage their exchange offers to later show superior operating performance.

In panel A, we use the percentage of firms that have positive operating cash flow to compare firms that use an investment bank to those that use a Section 3(a)(9) exchange offer. For the fiscal year just prior to the exchange offer, the proportion of Section 3(a)(9) firms with positive operating cash flow and the proportion of firms using an investment bank with positive operating cash flow are both approximately 70%. However, for the second year after a restructuring, the proportion of firms with positive cash flow that use an investment bank rises to 84%, while the proportion of firms with positive cash flow that choose a Section 3(a)(9) exchange falls to 47% (p‐value for difference equals 0.00). For the third year after restructuring, the corresponding percentages are 82% and 54% respectively (p‐value equals 0.06). Furthermore, for firms that use an investment bank, 86% have positive operating cash flow in 2 of the 3 years subsequent to the exchange offer and 81% have positive operating cash flow in all 3 years. The corresponding percentages for Section 3(a)(9) firms are 53% and 55%, respectively (p‐values for the differences are 0.01 and 0.09).

In this analysis, all regressions contain a dummy variable for investment bank involvement and a control dummy variable that takes on a value of one if the firm has positive operating cash flow in the year prior to the exchange offer and zero otherwise. Confirming the results in panel A, the probability that a firm generates a positive operating cash flow is positively related to the use of an investment bank in year 2 (significant at the 1% level) and year 3 (significant at the 5% level). The results of our tests of operating performance support the premise that investment‐bank involvement in exchange offers by distressed firms can more effectively resolve financial distress and avoid deterioration in operating performance. Although the two classes of firms show similar operating performance before the restructuring, those firms that choose to use an investment bank to facilitate their exchange perform significantly better in the years following the exchange offer. Firms that use an investment bank are more likely to generate positive operating cash flows and thus avoid subsequent economic distress. Firms that use investment banks later generate higher levels of operating cash flow relative to both sales and assets. They also demonstrate significantly greater improvement in operating performance. These results are robust to industry adjustment and to controls for potential selection bias.

sec.label: VI.
sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: Our evidence suggests that distressed firms choose investment‐bank‐managed exchange offers when they have a critical need to mitigate impediments to debt reduction and resolve financial distress. Investment banks are involved in exchange offers by larger firms, which have larger transaction costs arising from complex negotiations, and in restructurings in which firms seek greater debt reduction. We also find that firms that undertake investment‐bank‐managed‐exchanges offer a larger percentage of junior securities. This finding supports the premise that investment banks certify the value of the securities offered.

Although Section 3(a)(9) exchange offers are completed at a higher rate than investment‐bank‐managed exchanges, restructurings facilitated by investment banks achieve significantly more debt reduction, which leads to significantly better postrestructuring operating performance. These results suggest that investment‐bank‐managed exchange offers contribute more toward the resolution of financial distress.

Our results also provide insight into the roles of commercial banks and investment banks in exchange offers by distressed firms. As the percentage of bank debt increases, the likelihood decreases that a firm uses an investment bank. However, when commercial banks make concessions, the likelihood of investment‐bank involvement increases. If the bank debt is more likely to be impaired, then a bank concession is critical to the success of the exchange offer.

Our results also suggest a complementary role for the two financial institutions. Firms are more likely to use the services of an investment bank when a commercial bank makes a concession. This finding suggests that investment banks provide additional economic benefits, including the reduction of information asymmetry or transaction costs.

Investment banks are not necessary to conduct public‐debt exchange offers and involving them in the offer is costly to the firm. Yet, consistent with the idea that they provide economic benefits to the firm, 61% of the firms in our sample choose to use an investment bank as an intermediary in their exchange offers. Studies of investment banks in other financial transactions find support for the reduction of information asymmetry in initial public offerings and the reduction in transaction costs in acquisitions. We find that both roles provide a rationale for the involvement of investment banks in public‐debt exchange offers by distressed firms.
